questions.question: Which of the following is the most powerful example of social cohesion in socialorganisation?
Which of the following is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader?
questions.explanation: A mob is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader.Temporary social groups can be classified into:• Crowd- It is a temporary group motivated by a common interest or curiosity. It lacks an internalorganization and has no leader.• Mob- It is a crowd with a leader, and is more emotional than a crowd. It is unstable and has nointernal organization.••Herd- This social group has a leader and the members have to follow his/her orders withoutquestion.A band is a permanent spatial group that constitutes a few families living together. Otherpermanent spatial groups are villages, cities, towns and the state.

questions.question: In urbanized and industrialized countries, occupation is a major determinant of all of thefollowing except:
questions.explanation: Occupation is not a determinant of community participation.Occupation in most urbanized and industrialized communities is a major determinant of:• Economic rewards• Extent of authority•Extent of obligations• Degree of status• Values and lifestyles

questions.question: Which of the following is not a limitation of classifying social class according to occupation?

options.B: Inequality between men and women in the same jobs

questions.explanation: Most classifications of social class based on occupation take skills into consideration. Occupation is a useful measure of social differentiation, particularly in communities that are highly industrialized and urbanized. Limitations of occupational classification of social class: Heterogeneous grouping - occupations grouped together are not usually related to each other. Occupational mobility - occupations practiced by the members of a social class, as well as the perception of a certain occupation in the hierarchy, may change over a period of time. Gender biases - the same occupation may be considered as belonging to a superior class for men as compared to women.

questions.question: In the doctor-patient relationship, which of the following is not a level of communication?516
questions.explanation: Communication on a psychological plane is not a level of communication in a doctor-patientrelationship.For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communicationon the following levels:• Communication on an emotional plane: To build rapport, ensure openness and incite trust fromthe patient.•Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs,his/her cultural factors that may influence health and disease and also for economicunderstanding of the patient.•Communication on an intellectual plane: To give adequate explanation for their conditions andhelp the patients develop insight into their ailments.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best-suited role for a medical social worker?

options.B: Designing coping strategies, interviewing, and case work

questions.explanation: A medical social worker is a person who is trained mainly in social work and interviewing. He/she carries out duties that augment public and community healthcare by way of identifying, understanding, and relaying important information about a patient's determinants of health. They are not involved in active treatment, prescribing, or providing economic support.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to describe an interview used to note the gradual influence ofsome social or psychological process?
questions.explanation: A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychologicalprocess. A record is maintained to understand the changes.Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. A proper interviewtechnique must be employed to achieve the objective.Aims of an interview:• To secure information usually through face to face association and to understand theindividual/group being interviewed.• To form a hypothesis.• To collect personal data for quantitative purposes.•• To collect data from secondary sources of information.Types of interviews:.• A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence.• A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn't have any sequence of questions setbeforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences oropinions.•A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communication like radio broadcastsor film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem anddraws responses from people.• A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychologicalprocess. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

questions.question: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy for a well-baby check-up. Upon examination thepaediatrician diagnoses her son with hidden hunger. What is meant by the term hiddenhunger?

options.A: Child's diet is deficient in carbohydrates
options.C: Child is taking a diet that is deficient in essential amino acids
options.D: Child suffers from deficiency of omega 3 fatty acids

questions.explanation: Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiency. It occurs when there is deficiency in intake orabsorption of micronutrients like vitamins, iron, zinc, etc.The health effects of these deficiencies are less obvious or invisible and thus referred to as hiddenhunger. The consequences of hidden hunger are seen in all ages.526

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the estimation of poverty line?

options.B: Per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 per day in rural areas
options.C: Daily calorie intake of 2100 calories in urban areas
options.D: Daily calorie intake of 2700 calories in rural areas

questions.explanation: An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of 2100 inurban areas and 2400 in rural areas, per person.Income-based poverty line in India is per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 in urban areas and Rs. 32in rural areas per day.

questions.question: Which of the following legislations does not offer social security for industrial workers?
questions.explanation: The Labour Charter Act does not offer social security for industrial workers. Social security is the security that society furnishes through appropriate organization, against certain risks to which its members are exposed. These risks include sickness, maternity, old age, and death. Social security for industrial workers is given by: Workmen's Compensation Act, The Family Pension Scheme, Central Maternity Benefit Act, and Employees' State Insurance Act. Social security for civil servants is given by governments in the form of pension, gratuity, provident fund, etc. The Central Government Health Scheme provides security to employees of the Central Government. Insurance schemes from the likes of Life Insurance Corporation of India, etc., have security schemes for the general public.

questions.question: 519Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?

options.D: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.explanation: The infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index.The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measuredby indicators.GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X standardised CWA) + (1/6 X standardised CST) +(1/3 X Standardised CM)Where,•• PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished•• CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age• CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age527• CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age.The result lies on a scale from o to 100, with o meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score.The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries. In the 2022, India's GHI stands at 29.1, and Indiaranks 107th out of the 121 countries.DimensionsInadequate food supplyChild mortalityChild undernutritionIndicatorsProportion of the populationundernourishedUnder 5 mortality rateWasting in children under 5yearsStunting in children under 5 years528
